Introduction.Background: There are 27 coral islands in the group. Captain William KEELING discovered the islands in 1609, but they remained uninhabited until the 19th century. From the 1820s to 1978, members of the CLUNIE-ROSS family controlled the islands and the copra produced from local coconuts. Annexed by the UK in 1857, the Cocos Islands were transferred to the Australian Government in 1955. Apart from North Keeling Island, which lies 30 kilometers north of the main group, the islands form a horseshoe-shaped atoll surrounding a lagoon. North Keeling Island was declared a national park in 1995 and is administered by Parks Australia. The population on the two inhabited islands generally is split between the ethnic Europeans on West Island and the ethnic Malays on Home Island.

Geography.Location: Southeastern Asia, group of islands in the Indian Ocean, southwest of Indonesia, about halfway between Australia and Sri Lanka
Geography.Area - comparative: about 24 times the size of The Mall in Washington, DC

Area.note: includes the two main islands of West Island and Home Island

Geography.Climate: tropical with high humidity, moderated by the southeast trade winds for about nine months of the year
Geography.Natural hazards: cyclone season is October to April
Geography.Environment - current issues: freshwater resources are limited to rainwater accumulations in natural underground reservoirs
Geography.Geography - note: islands are thickly covered with coconut palms and other vegetation; site of a World War I naval battle in November 1914 between the Australian light cruiser HMAS Sydney and the German raider SMS Emden; after being heavily damaged in the engagement, the Emden was beached by her captain on North Keeling Island

Government.Dependency status: non-self governing territory of Australia; administered from Canberra by the Department of Regional Australia, Local Government, Arts and Sport
Government.Constitution: 23 November 1955 (Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955); amended many times, last in 2010 (2010)
Government.Legal system: common law based on the Australian model

Capital.name: West Island
Capital.time difference: UTC+6.5 (11.5 hours ahead of Washington, DC, during Standard Time)

Government.Legislative branch: unicameral Cocos (Keeling) Islands Shire Council (7 seats)

Executive branch.chief of state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952) represented by the Australian governor general
Executive branch.elections: held every two years with half the members standing for election; last held in October 2011 (next to be held in October 2013)

Government.Political pressure groups and leaders: The Cocos Islands Youth Support Centre
Government.Flag description: the flag of Australia is used

Judicial branch.highest court(s): under the terms of the Territorial Law Reform Act 1992, Western Australia provides court services as needed for the island including the Supreme Court and subordinate courts (District Court, Magistrate Court, Family Court, Children's Court, and Coroners' Court)

National anthem.note: as a territory of Australia, "Advance Australia Fair" remains official as the national anthem, while "God Save the Queen" serves as the royal anthem (see Australia)

Economy.Economy - overview: Coconuts, grown throughout the islands, are the sole cash crop. Small local gardens and fishing contribute to the food supply, but additional food and most other necessities must be imported from Australia. There is a small tourist industry.

Labor force - by occupation.note: the Cocos Islands Cooperative Society Ltd. employs construction workers, stevedores, and lighterage workers; tourism is the other main source of employment

Communication.Broadcast media: 1 local radio station staffed by community volunteers; satellite broadcasts of several Australian radio and TV stations available (2009)

Telephone system.general assessment: telephone service is part of the Australian network; an operational local mobile-cellular network available; wireless Internet connectivity available
Telephone system.international: country code - 61; telephone, telex, and facsimile communications with Australia and elsewhere via satellite; satellite earth station - 1 (Intelsat) (2001)

Military.Military - note: defense is the responsibility of Australia; the territory has a five-person police force
